title: Star Wars Destiny Card Box & Chit Holder

description.text:
If you get a second, check out my Kickstarter for other awesome things I've been working on!
https://www.kickstarter.com/projects/goodknightgamesllc/unlocked-the-mansion-of-mana

This is a remix of gt876a's lid. I loved the box lid but made some improvements so that an entire Destiny dice+30 card deck+characters (sleeved)+chits can all fit in a nice cube.

The clamshell box comes in 2 pieces. The top incorporates a slot for a sleeved 30 card deck (with 3 characters). A small inset allows for a flat 32mm x 2mm magnet and a ribbon to be glued in. Then the cards are placed in and finally the ribbon is wrapped around and another magnet is placed on top of the cards, effectively binding the cards to the top of the cube and holding the ribbon. The ribbon is then used to easily and carefully remove the cards from the cube when it is time to play.

The middle of the clamshell holds your dice thanks to - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2004370

The bottom of the clamshell holds 4 different kinds of tokens in their own areas. The dice cube sits atop the insets holding the tokens in place.

There are holes in all 4 corners of the insets to allow for small 3-5mm rare earty magnets allow the top and bottom of the cube to 'click' into place... using the power of the force! what force? magnetic force of course.

This setup allows a player to grab your 'cube' and include everything you need for a Luke/Ackbar or Han\Rey or Vader\Raider. The simplicity of a single cube like this has a player ready to play in about 1 minute, assuming you keep your tokens in their built in organizer.

description.text:
NOTE: THIS PART IS ONLY ONE SIDE. FROM YOU SLICER YOU WILL NEED TO USE THE MIRROR FEATURE TO GET OPPOSITE HAND PART.

This part is designed for the Duplicator 4s to allow for easy removal and placement of the side plexiglass. I have found that when printing PLA my full enclosure can get warm enough to negatively affect my prints.

By adding these holders it makes it so that it is a tool less operation to remove the side plexiglass if desired for a printing process, as well as making it easier to clean the inside of the enclosure.

I was able to reuse the factory hardware that was originally holding the plexi in place so no need to buy any hardware. New holes will need to be drilled to mount these. When marking the holes, leave the plexi bolted in place with the top two screws, hold the brackets firmly up against the glass, mark the hole positions, remove the plexi, drill, reuse factor bolts for new pieces, and slide the plexi back in place.

I would recommend removing the entire side panel for this process.

Printer:

Wanhao Duplicator 4s

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

user choice, I use .2mm

Notes:

My machine isn't listed, but is a Duplicator 4s. I used PLA for these parts but use whatever material you like, and set your settings to what works best for you. I used 15% infill which is over kill for these parts but I just used a settings profile in my slicer that was already set up and I knew would give good results in the first shot.

I didn't use any supports or a raft and printed with the flat area down. I had to clean out the counter sink holes a little but that was a piece of cake

Minimal Clean up should be required for this part. It is designed to be printed with no supports or raft. If you printer is decently tuned you should have no issues with these. Only cleanup will be in the counter sink holes where the bolt heads will go.

Design Process

Supper simple, measured the plexi and used SolidWorks to model up the above piece.

I have also included the SolidWorks part file so that you can edit as you desire. If you would like a different file format message me and I will see if I can provide it for you.

description.text:
Cufflink design inspired from "Star Wars Cufflinks" by belch with rotating lock for easy wearing.   
Make any cufflink by importing your own stl motif in the OpenSCAD files.  
Or print the examples given.   
Happy New Year 2014!

Printed with 2 shells and 100% infill PLA using 0.1 mm resolution on the Makerbot Replicator 2 using rafts. Rafts are good to prevent fusion of the rotating rod that locks. If tolerance is a problem (and the locking rod cannot rotate) modify the OpenSCAD file. A pair of cufflinks will typically print in less than 1 hour. The OpenSCAD files can be easily be modified to use any motif (use e.g. the heart version). The LEGO and Dice version can be printed without support.
The LEGO version fits in the bottom of a standard LEGO brick
The New Year 2014 versions are made in dual colour by changing filament during print using Z pause at 15 mm (including raft).
The gold colored versions are painted and so is the Makebot logo.
The brilliant cut stones (5 mm Zirconia) were obtained from a commercial source (http://www.mg-quartz.de/)

Remixed and inserted the SMU Mustang logo. Kept the outline design of the original. Printed on my MP Maker Select Mini at 0.175 layer height and 50% infill. You will need supports as the Mustang logo is not flush with the bottom but centered inside the keychain. Also this thing is huge so resize accordingly. I resized to 8% of original and it seems to be about the right size for a keychain. Takes about 45 min to print one.

UPDATE: Uploaded individual pieces of this project in case you would like to print them in different colors.

mustangkeychain_blank.stl is the blank keychain with a solid back. Print this @ 8% size.
mustangkeychain_insert.stl is a insert that goes inside the blank. Print this @ 7.8% size.
mustangkeychain_horse.stl is the SMU Mustang logo. Print this @ 7.5% size.

I glue the different parts in with super glue but you could use whatever adhesive you'd like. Since they are now separate you could substitute any logo you'd like. Just size it accordingly. An easy way to figure out what size you need load the blank STL and your logo STL into Cura. Set the blank at 8% of it's original size (or whatever you choose) then drag your logo over the top of the blank then play around with resizing until you get a nice fit. Once resized, move it back to another part of the build plate.

title: Differential Locker for Hobby King Rattler

description.text:
EDIT: Have uploaded the MK4 after realising in error in thinking. Also...printing in abs is not recomended. I may have slightly shattered a drive pin with the Mk2 in ABS. Gonna see how mk 4 in PLA goes.

So after I upgraded to a 3674 motor (yes excessive I know) I completely destroyed my rear diff gears. Since HK didn't have replacements in stock, I just decided to go for a full locked diff and avoid the issue.

If you are mad enough to try simmilar things, strip out your diff, remove the bevel gears, but leave the pins in the drive cups/shafts. You may wanna decrease the interior. This part then slips into the middle of the diff housing and the drive shafts/pins should fit into the holes/slots on this part. Then just rinse repeat with other side. Be warned, depending on how accurate your printer is you may need to give it a bit of a file to level the part out.

Again, be warned this is the result of madness. No liability is taken :P

author: happless

description.text:
This Thing lets you efficiently check that your entire print bed is leveled across the entire surface. I keep it on my SD card so I can quickly print it before starting a print, which improves the success rate of my printing considerably.  
I've attached the STL of the version that I use (Replicator, 0.1, 0.2 and 0.3 mm height.  
It's customizable so you can enter your print bed size, height and width.

Use the Customizer to generate a print bed leveler for your print bed and layer height. If you have a Replicator (original) you can use the STL files attached here.  
Print it. The plastic should be the same color and width across the entire print bed.  
If the layer gets squished too thin and breaks up, lower that area of the print bed.  
If the layer is lighter, narrower or doesn't stick to the print bed at all, raise that area of the print bed.  
On the Replicator, the bed leveling screws are on the corners. So if the area to adjust is in the middle, adjust both screws on that side equally.  
Repeat printing and adjusting until the print is level across the entire print bed.

title: HyperCube Redesigned E3D Fan Duct
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a collection of some slightly redesigned fan ducts for the HyperCube 3D printer. Like many, I was having issues printing the fan duct. I tried using the fan duct from arturslab's redesigned parts for Hypercube 3d printer that is slightly modified to be printed vertically & still had issues with printing the bridges at the top. These 3 versions make it a bit easier to print and more sturdy (the original is completely hollow). I have not tested these yet. I'm merely in the early stages of building my HyperCube & printing off the parts on my existing printer.

Print these with a brim otherwise adhesion might be an issue.

The first version just introduces a bit of reinforcement in the middle of the duct. This makes the duct MUCH more sturdy but I still had some issues with the top of the print. All subsequent versions include this reinforcement

The second version makes the top angle about 1mm thicker. The duct is still ultimately the same length. This prints much better but the tip is still thin & a little droopy/bumpy.

The third version is a full redesign of the top with a 45 degree angle. This version printed beautifully but since the angle is steeper, the tip is thinner and may reduce airflow.

Huge shoutout to Tech2C for designing this amazing printer. You can find his designs here

description.text:
My son got some paw patrol toys this christmas, and they included some clip on badges; unfortunately the clip that holds them on his shirt was lost.

This is a replacement clip to hold these badges in place. I've seen these types of clips on other similar clip on things; so it might be useful for other toys... either way the scad file is included and is fairly easy to customize.

Parameters:

dimension = 38;         // overall width and length of base

description.text:
I made the switch to safety razors awhile back because the cost of blades for "new" razors is getting ridiculous. A friend started turning his own handles out of acrylic and gifted me one, as I was starting to run out of room I needed a place to hang my razor so I made this.

There are two versions, one full size stand that can either lay down or be attached with suction cups, and a smaller version that is primarily meant to be attached by suction cups.

I made these specifically for the razors my friend makes but I found they fit other handles. I've included the sketchup files as well in case anyone needs to tweak it for their razor.

Just FYI the suction cups I used are from the dollar store, they come with a little metal hook that you'll need to pop off before you can insert them into the holder. The suction cups seem fairly universal, they're about 1" in diameter and I've seen a few brands that are all virtually identical.

Most of my models are designed with a 0.4mm nozzle in mind and are generally printed at 0.4mm layer height.

The little square block that is included with the Small Holder model is to help stabilize it once you try to attach it to a surface with the suction cups. You'll need to glue it into the recessed area on the backside of the model. The large version doesn't need it because it has 4 suction cups and the weight is distributed better.

title: Age of Sail Wargaming Miniatures
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
WORK IN PROGRESS

UPDATE (8-Aug-17) Added a version of the gun-brig with crude details striped and thinned gunwales for printing at larger scales (by request).

UPDATE: (23-Apr-17) Added a Santísima Trinidad model that's a roughly hacked version of my existing HMS Victory.

UPDATE (20-Apr-17): Added open port versions of all the models based on feedback from joxash.

UPDATE (17-Apr-17): Added A brig sloop based on the pre-refit HMS Beagle. I've been having better success with paper sails than printed, and I've uploaded some templates and instruction for how I do them using 16 Ga wire masts. As Requested, I've uploaded a model of the masts/spars only if you want to use paper sails that way.

UPDATE (05-Apr-17): Added 4th rate hull based on the 50-gun HMS Leopard.

UPDATE (03-Apr-17): A couple Sloop-of-War's are still to come. I've bee playing with printing, painting, rigging and basing these. I haven't decided if I like paper sails better, or not. If there's interest, I can post the templates for paper sails too.

UPDATE (14-Mar-17): Uploaded a 2nd Rate Ship of the Line, loosely based on the HMS London. Also added sails without a mast that could be glued to your own mast, as requested. The sails, admittedly, need work. Particularly the mast diameters and their mating holes in the hulls. I'm working on it.

UPDATE (10-Mar-17): I just added a 3rd rate and a 5th rate (Frigate). I also added a new style sails that has lighter canvas and heavier masts look better and be sturdier, but it requires support to print. I had a couple turn out well and a couple not - may still need tweaking. If you want the beefier support-less sails for the new ships, you can print the original HMS Victory sails scaled at 90% for the 3rd rate and 80% for the frigate. I also added a longboat that can be glued to the deck of the SOLs above the hold, if you like.

This is the first of (what I plan to be) a series of model ships from the age of fighting sail for miniature wargaming.

I'm currently reading a bunch (too many) rules sets, but I'm most interested in/excited by:

Fighting Sail: Fleet Actions 1775–1815, My current favorite - this is just the right scale / complexity balance for me - and written by a fellow Man o' War fan!

Bloody Broadsides My leading contender for a hex-based game. Not too complex. The pre-planned movement appeals to me.

Also:
Captaincy seems very deep, and complex, but fascinating.
Fire As She Bears seems to be popular, and the movement octagons are cool!.
Signal Close Action, Fast Play (although I don't have this one, I've just read good things)...

I'm very interested in comments/feedback/suggestions on these rule systems... or the models!

I'm working in 1:1000 scale, but I've also provided beefed up masts & sails that can be scaled down as low as 1:2400 successfully. The photo is the HMS Victory printed at 1:1000, 1:1200 (83.33%) & 1:2400 (41.66%).

To narrow my focus, I've start with the Napoleonic era, but I'll freely admit that I am in no way a historian, so you'll have to grant me some leeway.

There are a few models from this periods around, but most are not suited for gaming.

Eventually I want to model enough ships to give a good selection for gaming:

[X] A 104-gun 1st rate Ship of the line (HMS Victory)
[X ] A 98-gun 2nd rate Ship of the line (HMS London)
[X] A 74-gun 3rd rate Ship of the line (HMS Berwick)
[X] A 50-gun 4th rate / Large Frigate
[X] A 32-gun Frigate
[ ] A 20+-gun Post Ship?
[ ] A Ship-Sloop?
[X] A 10-gun Brig-Sloop

I'm leaning heavily on the wonderful free plans available at http://www.shipmodell.com

Drill out mast holes and insert.

OR... Cut and insert 16 Ga wire masts, print, cut and punt paper sails (see PDF for instructions) and slide over masts.

title: C8 Camera Mount Assembly
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a 3-piece print which provides rail-mount brackets for a camera to piggy-back on a Celestron 8" Schmidt-Cassegrains, "C8" telescope.

This assembly is fitted for the older model C8, CeleStar Deluxe with the double fork equatorial mount and an under-rail for weights, c1998.

Post-Print Assembly

Materials List
• The three C8 Camera Mount Assembly prints
o C8 Front Bracket
o C8 Rear Bracket
o C8 Camera Bracket

• 1 – U-channel aluminum rail, 1" x ½" x 13-1/8" (6063-T52 Al chan, sharp corner)
• 2 – ¼" x 1" bolts
• 1 – ¼" x ½" machine screw
• 2 – ¼" nut
• 2 – #8-32 x ¾" (1" will work too) machine screws
• 1 – #10-24 x 1" machine screw
• 1 – Manfrotto 323 RC2 System, Quick Release Adapter
https://www.bhphotovideo.com/c/product/554141-REG/Manfrotto_323_323_RC2_System_Quick.html

Caution: Inserting screws into your telescope mounting holes can damage or misalign the optical elements. Finger-test the fit of all screws before inserting with tools. Do not over-tighten the screws.

Rail Preparation – cut and drill the aluminum rail

  1. Cut the rail to about 13-1/8" long (test fit on your scope for precise length)
  2. Drill a ¼" diameter hole, centered side-to-side and positioned about 0.350" from the front face of the rail. Label this hole "A". You can use the C8 Front Bracket to mark the drill point of this hole.
  3. Drill a ¼" diameter hole, centered side-to-side and positioned about 1.275" from the front face of the rail. Label this hole "B". You can use the C8 Front Bracket to mark the drill point of this hole.
  4. Drill a ¼" diameter hole, centered side-to-side and positioned about 0.5" from the rear face of the rail. Label this hole "C".
  5. Drill a ¼" diameter hole, centered side-to-side at a position along the rail for mounting your camera (I used 10” from the front). Multiple holes can be drilled for C8 Camera Bracket and further back the position, the balanced the telescope will be. Label this hole "D".

Assembly

  1. Insert the #10-24 into the forward counter-bore hole of the C8 Front Bracket—this will sit under the aluminum rail and can be accessed through hole A
  2. Insert a ¼" hex nut into the bottom counter-bore hex-hole of the C8 Front Bracket
  3. Fit a ¼" x 1" bolt through hole B of the rail and into the matching hole (with nut) on the C8 Front Bracket. Thread the bolt into the nut finger-tight.
  4. Insert a ¼" hex nut into the bottom counter-bore hex-hole of the C8 Rear Bracket
     
  5. Fit a ¼" x 1" bolt through hole C of the rail, into the matching hole (with nut) on the C8 Rear Bracket. Thread the bolt into the nut finger-tight.
  6. Fit a ¼" x 3/8" machine screw through hole D from the bottom (in the Al U-channel), through the C8 Camera Bracket, and tighten into the Manfrotto 323 bracket quick-release
  7. Insert two #8-32 x ¾" machine screws into the top counter-bore holes of the C8 Rear Bracket
  8. Fit the whole assembly onto your C8 and attach the C8 Camera Mount Assembly
    a. Locate one of the mounting holes on the ‘rear cell’ of the C8, place the C8 Rear Bracket near one of these mounting hoes, and finger tighten one of the #8 screws into the rear cell
    b. Locate the ‘front cell’ mounting hole, place the C8 Front Bracket near the hole, lightly tighten the pre-inserted #10 screw through access hole A
    c. Tighten the 3 mounting screws and 2 bolts connecting the brackets to the rail

This was my second project using OnShape, free subscription (started before "public" requirement).

The front and rear brackets were designed first with 4 revisions after test-fits on my C8. Drawings were created later (for my first posting to Thingiverse) and exported to provide dimensions.

The camera bracket was created and run through several test fits with the aluminum rail and the Manfrotto quick-release.

To be improved
• Match the shoulder angles on the C8 Front Bracket
• Consider having the Manfrotto 323 RC2 sit flush with the C8 Camera Bracket (the current offset allows for tight indexing)

title: Tabletop Tri-Mode Spring Motor Rolling Chassis

description.text:
Tabletop Tri-Mode Spring Motor Rolling Chassis adds yet another mode to my previous spring motor designs, "pull back windup".

While this small vehicle will not outperform my previous designs for distance, it does add a third mode "pull back windup" to the power and true coast modes of my previous floating pinion designs (here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2054125 and here: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2025760). The previous designs utilized a single floating pinion ("Drive Pinion") that allowed the vehicle to truly coast by disengaging the rear axle from the spring motor, but depended on a knob or key to wind the spring. This design adds a second floating pinion ("Wind Pinion") that provides the mechanism for winding the spring by rapidly rolling the vehicle in reverse, thus no knob or key are required.

Video of prototype is here: https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nYvMv_0V4Kw.

You will need to purchase 12 "AS 568" size 221 (1 7/16 O.D., 1 11/16 I.D., 1/8" diameter) o-rings for the tires.

I probably forgot a file or two or something, so if you have any questions, please feel free to ask.

Designed using Fusion 360, sliced using Cura 2.3.1, and printed in PLA on an Ultimaker 3 Extended.

Printer Brand:

Ultimaker

Printer:

Ultimaker 3 Extended

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.1mm

Infill:

100%, 20% (see Misc Notes)

Notes:

I printed "Spring.stl", "Gear Spring.stl" and all axles at 100%, the remaining components at 20%.

Prior to assembly, test fit and trim, file, sand, etc. all parts as necessary for smooth movement of moving surfaces, and tight fit for non moving surfaces. Depending on the colors you chose and your printer settings, more or less trimming, filing and/or sanding may be required.

Study "Assembly.stl", carefully noting the locations and positions of the various components as assembly proceeds.

I assembled Table Top Tri-Mode Spring Motor Rolling Chassis as follows:

1) Press both "Gear Axle Rear.stl" onto "Axle Rear.stl".

2) Assemble "Spring.stl", "Gear Spring.stl" and "Cap Gear Spring.stl" onto "Axle Spring.stl".

3) Press "Axle Gear Idler Small.stl" into "Gear Idler Small.stl" for both gear idler small assemblies.

4) Press "Axle Gear Idler Large.stl" into "Chassis Right.stl".

5) Press the axle spring assembly into "Chassis Right.stl".

6) Position one of the gear idler small assemblies into "Chassis Right.stl", then press "Chassis Center.stl" into "Chassis Right.stl". Note the gear idler small assembly must freely spin and slide in the guide slot. This is the "Wind Pinion".

7) Position one "Gear Idler Large.stl" onto "Axle Gear Idler Large.stl".

8) Position "Spacer Axle Gear Idler Large.stl" onto "Axle Gear Idler Large.stl".

9) Position the remaining "Gear Idler Large.stl" onto "Axle Gear Idler Large.stl".

10) Position the remaining gear idler small assembly into "Chassis Center.stl". This is the "Drive Pinion".

11) Position the rear axle assembly into the chassis right assembly.

12) Press "Chassis Left.stl" onto "Chassis Right.stl". Note that all gears must move freely.

13) Press "Axle Front.stl" into one "Wheel Front.stl". Slide the assembly into the chassis assembly, then press the remaining "Wheel Front.stl" onto the remaining end of "Axle Front.stl".

14) Press both "Wheel Rear.stl" onto each end of the rear axle assembly.

15) At this point, the chassis should easily roll forward when pushed forward. When the chassis is rapidly moved in reverse, the winding floating pinion (the pinion adjacent to "Chassis Right.stl") should engage and cause a winding of the spring.

I do not recommend exceeding a 30" total rollback distance in order to avoid spring failure and/or separation from the spring gear.

Hope you like it!

print_settings.Notes:: This was one of my first attempts at using supports, in Repetier they worked out alright but I wasn't thrilled. That being said it worked and other than a little filing here and there it looked pretty good.

description.text:
A figurine that I sculpted that may or may not be inspired by a comic or movie.

For the last few years I'd been making my girlfriend various figures out of polymer clay, last Christmas I decided since I have a 3D printer I should probably learn how to sculpt/design more organic shapes. I was amazed that a program like Sculptris was available for free and after some swearing at the interface I finally started to get something that resembled the merc who hails from the city that rhymes with fun.

Optional base included which the model would need to be glued onto, I can't remember if he stood on his own well or not. Also, this guy doesn't exactly have a "kung-fu grip" so the swords have to be glued into his hands.

Printer Brand:

Printrbot

Printer:

Printrbot Simple Metal

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Yes

Resolution:

0.4mm or lower

Infill:

25% or higher

Notes:

NOTE: You'll want to scale down to 50%. My apologies, the model was formed in Sculptris and then passed through 3D Builder to simplify. Sculpting is very new to me and I'm still working out kinks. I can't remember if the weapons were scaled properly, I think they may need to be shrunk as well.

This was one of my first attempts at using supports, in Repetier they worked out alright but I wasn't thrilled. That being said it worked and other than a little filing here and there it looked pretty good.

On it's own it won't look like much until you paint it. I mainly use cheap dollar store paints for the first coats, then if I'm just not getting the right colour or enough coverage I'll use some Golden paints. Most of the stuff I've done over the years though is just using the cheap stuff.

Printing at 0.4mm leaves some layer ridges but they are hardly noticeable after a few coats of paint. If you print at 0.2mm of lower this will be obviously be less noticeable.

On later models (which I'll post soon) I tried using wood filler which actually worked really well!

At the end I always use a clear coat of glossy Mod Podge to seal it up.

I discovered Sculptris which is a free "lite" version of Z-Brush. Just because it's free doesn't mean it's not incredibly powerful. I will say this though, the user interface is not intuitive. I've got lots of experience in Sketchup/Photoshop/Inkscape etc and everything in Sculptris felt backwards. Eventually I got the hang of it though, swearing seemed to help.

description.text:
This is a simple door stopper that you can customize. Create 3D business cards that are useful and won\'t be lost ... Door stopper V1 comes in two versions:
  • Simple: You can add text on top
  • Normal: You also can add text underneath
    • Door stopper V2 is a bit smaller and has a cut off top These models were made with OpenScad ( http://openscad.org )and you also can customize the *.scad files.

Printing will be difficult with ABS since it will warp. If you print with a RapMan or similar, make sure to make a fat and hot raft. PLA printing on the other hand is easy (see the blue example picture), but it won't be as solid. More tips are inside the *.scad files. Customizing: Create 3D letters with a tool like Sketchup or Netfabb ( http://www.netfabb.com/ ) . Then merge with a tool like Meshlab ( http://meshlab.sourceforge.net/ ) or OpenScad. Netfabb pro (commercial) is the easiest solution. Positioning:
  • Text underneath should be 3mm high with Z = 0
  • Text on top for door-stopper-2.stl: Z = 7.5

print_settings.Notes:: First print was with a brim, I wouldn't advise it, and supports, which take a while to clean out, but isn't the worst idea. A raft is a bad idea, the bottom lift plate would have trouble separating. I would print the thinnest possible sturdy setting, and keep the print hollow if able. remixed_from.author: Intentional3D
remixed_from.title: Improved Deck Box with Gears for Magic the Gathering EDH Commander

remixed_from.author: destroyer2012
remixed_from.title: Non-warping complex deck box with spring

description.text:
Hey guys. So, I wanted a cool deck holder for my Magic: The Gathering Commander Deck. I really liked the look of destroyer2012's box, but I needed it commander sized for sleeved decks. Enter Intentional3D's box. I laid the pattern of the destroyer box onto the sides of Intentional's box, adjusting for size, and making the hinge holes larger. I added a little more solid corners on the box, one of my tests broke on the corner, fitting the lift platform section in. I put all the pieces I could fit inside the box, made it just one file to print out.

The following pieces are direct from other builds and can be reprinted seperately if needed:
-Long Hinge
-Pinion Gear Covers
-Rack
-Bottom Lift Plate
-Hing Pieces
-Pinion Gear Cover

(Actually, I dont really remember if that's true. I might have edited the hinge spacing and sizes. If someone has trouble, hit me up and I'll add individual parts to the build as I sort them out)
I definitely widened the hinge holes, makes it easier to thread wire to hold it all together.

Printer:

DaVinci Jr

Rafts:

No

Supports:

Doesn't Matter

Resolution:

.4mm

Infill:

Hollow

Notes:

First print was with a brim, I wouldn't advise it, and supports, which take a while to clean out, but isn't the worst idea. A raft is a bad idea, the bottom lift plate would have trouble separating. I would print the thinnest possible sturdy setting, and keep the print hollow if able. This is most important for the long hinges that connect the Pinion Gear Covers, there was little tolerance for a thicker printing. the pegs tended to tear the long hinge's socket.

Miscellaneous suggestions

So, if you do supports be sure to clear out the supports INSIDE the long hinges. The Gear cover peg is almost perfectly sized to fit in the socket.

comments.author: Liriel666

comments.text: Just printed mine, works great. As for the suggested lock, I think I've got a very quick and easy solution: Move the rails up (to the tip) by about 0.75mm. If you hold the Joy-Con Grip next to the rail, you'll notice that there's about 1cm space with no rail on the top end and the two pegs for the locking mechanism are around 0.75mm into the rail. While I haven't tried it, this looks a lot like simply moving the rail would make the locking mechanism work, without one having to fear that it somehow locks forever or breaks (because there's no rail to dig into). Instead the pegs would keep the rail from sliding out..

title: Low Voltage - Terminal Block - 12 post - 45 degree

description.text:
NEW parametric version at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2171007.

USE AT OWN RISK!

Low voltage terminal block with 12 posts set at 45 degrees for easier wire insertion, and easier printing.

Bill of Materials:
1x printed terminal block
12x #4-40x3/8" screws
12x #4-40 nuts (1/4" Across Flats)
24x #4 flat washers (3/8" Outside Diameter)
2x Countersunk screws to mount.

For general use, two wires should fit nicely between the nut and the washer.

Using either aluminum tape, copper tape, or a wire, you can bridge/bond posts across from each other.

Not recommended for high voltage or high amperage. I am not an electrical engineer, so I will limit its use to 12VDC on a 3D printer, or similar projects.

If you mount it to metal, I recommend covering the bottom with electrical tape.

These are DXF designs of the side plates for the tensioners, you can send these files to a laser cutter and they will be able to produce alloy versions of the side brackets. You will still need to print out the mechanism parts using Banholm's design.

I had these cut in 4mm and they work very well.

title: Temperature Calibration Tower for Anycubic PLA

description.text:
I really liked the temperature calibration tower by fanlabise - http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1956512 - but the Anycubic PLA I just bought off Amazon - https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B017R4OPU2 - is rated between 190 and 230 degrees... slightly out of the range of the original tower. I added an extra step and relabeled the temperature marks.

As with the original, you will have to modify your gcode temperature each centimeter (10mm). This can be done relative easily with the Post Processing | Modify G-Code extension in Cura.

-=[ EDIT ]=-
After printing this, I noticed that the text is not readable as is. I have scaled this up and embossed larger text. The new model is v2.

title: Improved heavy bed follower for 10mm rods
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
I designed this system as an upgrade to the 3DMS Scalar model, applicable to all Scalar models, with the intention of lateral cantilever load abatement I have been experiencing with linear bearings, and to greatly reduce the operational noise floor of the machine. I will be using this in conjunction with a trapezoidal lead screw (with a planetary transmission). This system can be used on other models using 8-10mm rods, but different Delrin V-groove runners will need to be used if you wish to retain the vertical orientation.

These are designed to used 25mm OD Delrin V-groove surround, with a guide rod preload of less than 0.5mm if the bottom bearing screw is removed (as pictured), or up to 2.5mm preload with the screw installed at varying tightness.

Enjoy, please observe the creative common licensing specified.

author: ceicui

title: AR15 80% Lower Milling Upright Jig for Drill Press

description.text:
A friend asked me to create a support for them to make finishing AR15 80% lowers on their drill press easier. The method he was currently using was putting a vise block in the magwell (specifically designed for this) and then clamp it down in a milling vise. This worked ok for him, but he had to monitor his angles very closely to make sure something did not move.

He asked me to design something for him that had a longer base and that could be bolted to the jig and the vise itself (not a clamping vise). He wanted to use his Proxxon vise (link below) so I designed this to be bolted to the clamping rails on that vise.

This design is for the lowers with a removable trigger guard. I decided not to pre-create the holes, but instead you should carefully drill through them so you can push pins or screws in to better hold.

This will tightly fit the lower. You may have to do a little rounding to the edges of the magwell portion depending on the cut of the lower. When using this, you will need to avoid excessive heat during the milling process (something you should do for 10+ other reasons anyhow) so that it does not warp due to the material.

I will post another item shortly for mounting the Proxxon vise to a craftsman drill press (though it may work on others too). So, this jig will bolt to the vise, and the vise will bolt to the drill press, which should eliminate most play from the process.

https://www.amazon.com/gp/product/B000S81MHY

Edit

I made these nearly a year ago and my buddy says he has made a number of lowers with them and that they are still working well! I am excited that these made things easier for him.

title: P802E Frame Braces(Y and Z Axis)

description.text:
a remix of Simhopp's and Mediocredesigns's wonderful frame braces, to fit a TronXY P802E.
these fit a P802E with 193.68mm center to center on the threaded rod.
and with the threaded rod 22.25mm from the base of the acrylic plate.
and now a 270.0mm Vertical Z axis brace.

update 3-25-17: lol i made a mistake and totally forgot how the vertical braces print, and made the left one unprintable. i've now fixed that with v17. also, the proper way to print the vertical braces is with the item 45 deg along the bed, and with the thin flat part down.

Update 3-20-17: with a suggestion from JackJakobs, i've put in an adjustable end stop mount on the left vertical brace. which was inspired by shadowtrk's design. i probably won't print this one out myself, since i have an inductive sensor on the way, but if you do print it out, let me know how well it works!

update 3-11-17: both vertical braces have been printed, they seem to stiffen up the top end of the machine well, but i think they could use some precision mounting on the base, so they are really locked in. i will add in a bolt hole so you can mount them to where the z-end stop bolts go.(done, v14) speaking of the z-end stop, i had to move it to the z end stop to where it's bracket mounts, and then move the bracket to the bottom of the X axis, and bolt it to the height adjustment bolt. it turned out to be almost perfect for the height of my bed. you can see the new position in the last photo.

update 3-10-17: now includes my remix of Mediocredesigns vertical frame braces. lengthened to 270.0mm and changed from circles to a hex design. these just BARELY fit onto the 214x214mm print bed. hehe

update: finally got both printed and installed, both fit my P802E perfectly. i'll consider these final for now.
in the pics: the rear brace was printed at a blistering 80mm/s and high acceleration (2500), so there is a lot of ringing and ghosting. (i changed the external & small perimeters to 25mm/s and the ghosting and ringing is almost gone, in case anybody wanted to know a simple fix)
update 2: added an alternate z end stop mount, that allows the braces to fit.

description.text:
Gcode file

The gcode file already has the extruder temperature adjusted, with the profile of my Malyan M150 printer (similar to Wanhao Duplicator i3, sharing profile with Pusa i3).

Customizer

Customized version of http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:915435

Created with Customizer! http://www.thingiverse.com/apps/customizer/run?thing_id=915435

Extruder temperature adjustment

If you slice the STL file, remember to adjust the temperature by editing the gcode file, or using the postprocessing command TweakAtZ in Cura. Start extruder temp at 245 ºC, 4reduce temp at 11 mm (1 mm base plus 10 mm block) to 240ºC, and then every 10 mm reduce by 5 ºC.

Customizer options

Using the following options:

Labels = [245,240,235,230,225,220,215,210]
DoYouUnderstandYouMustModifyTheGCodeThisMakes = 7
ReverseLabelOrder = 0
WallThickness = 1.2
fn_override = 0
TowerBase = [25,25,1]

FontFace = 2
TopOfTriangleThickness = 2

description.text:
Bumper for Moto 360 1st generation.

Design

This was designed for 0.4mm nozzle size, to have a 2 columns wall width (0.8mm), and fit perfectly to watch contours, modeling even the tiniest details. It is thin enough, to still fit in the wireless charging dock, but thick enough in tho top to be a little above the glass level to protect it. Rounded edges everywhere.

Material

This was printed in PLA, and have a "just perfect" fit, meaning it is a bit tough to put on the watch, but it fits perfectly once you finish (PLA has enough flexibility to allow it to get in). May also be printable with flexible filament (share your experience!).

Remixes

Original design publically available at Onshape: https://cad.onshape.com/documents/e68357ddf89991daa8ba89fa/w/a694a2f86468b0bd3eb4d95c/e/02b7d70266e3be5f9e597816

If you wish to change the thickness, edit "Bump Profile" Sketch and change the thickness from 0.8mm to a multiple of your nozzle size. Everything else should adapt to that change.

Original Prusa i3 MK2

description.text: This 130 size Drone was designed by Derek specifically for taking lots of abuse in the car park. While the ABS frames are pretty good Derek always seems to keep breaking them. This frame is carbon 2.5mm - 3mm. I have included the DXF. We got some cut by Bezerk RC for a pretty good price. We still use the red bottom emax 4000kv 1306 motors with 3 inch gemfan props. The Cicada 12A escs or the smaller Spedix 20A BlHeli-S escs from Multirotor shop. The CCD 1000TVL camera from Banggood and the new tiny Eachine 25/50/200 switchable VTX. The tiny Emax Femto Flight controller and a small Receiver. Derek has installed a super short 1.8 lense from surveilzone with IR block. 450mah Tattu or Joos batteries with XT30 connector. So far he has not managed to break the frame or ABS pod however he has dislodged several magnets from his motors with the hard crashes.

title: Proxxon Vise to Drill Press Mounting Plate

description.text:
I made this jig as part of a job for a friend (who is borrowing my Proxxon vise for his project) to securely mount to his Craftsman drill press. I think that the drill press base is pretty standard but I am not sure.

The vise will fit snugly in the mounting plate's grove (I had to heat the edges a little bit and snap it in) and allow you to bolt the vise down to the drill press base.

The tricky part of this, because of the vise itself, is getting the vice bolted to the mounting plate. So, I made two versions. One version, is flat and provides clearance, but does not bolt (i ended up drilling holes and threading bolts into it, but I do not think it will be very strong if stressed). The other has holes to bolt the vice to it, but it sits a bit higher.

Design part of project: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2154119

title: tiny Arduino nano V3 Box with drv8825 support

description.text:
Pour un projet personnel (moteur de mise au point d'un télescope), j'avais besoin de concevoir une boite compacte contenant un Arduino Nano V3 et un DRV8825.
Sur le côté de la boite, j'ai rajouté un orifice qui permet de brancher une prise pour l'alimentation.

Trop spécifique, j'ai décidé de créer un modèle et d'apprendre par la même occasion OpenSCAD.

Je me suis inspiré du modèle suivant : http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:1657153 qui me semblait répondre en partie à mon besoin.
Le modèle n'étant pas modifiable, je l'ai entièrement refait.

Le script permet de choisir les dimensions de la boite et on peut facilement rajouter ou modifier les orifices (passage de cable, position des supports...)

Geeetech Prusa I3 Pro C

No

No

0.25

30%

J'ai été obligé de limer les angles de la boite, mais c'est sûrement dû à un problème d'impression (température trop élevée) car les angles n'étaient pas nets.

I designed this Holder because my old one broke.
The design allows you to tilt and roll the shower head.

All you need are 3 pieces M6 x 16 (could be a little bit longer or shorter if necessary).
Ream the holes to 5.5mm before you insert the screws (no nuts needed)

Tighten the screws until you reach the desired resistance in the joints.

You can attach it to the wall with screws or by using double layer tape (3M VHB or so).

I used the "Laser Collimator for Telesope by Gyrobot" thing 101030 as a starting point and adapted the concept to use a laser boresighter that I inherited from my father. See the link below for a model that looks like the one I have. If I did not have the laser boresighter I would have chosen a cheap laser pointer in the $5 range or a cheaper boresighter in the $15 range. Perhaps I would have simply purchased a laser collimator for $20 rather than spend $15.

I adapted this design for my printer by reducing the OD of the 1.25" tube by .013" based on a test print of a hollow 1.25" cylinder. It was out of round and the worst oversize dimension was 1.258". My eyepieces seem to be .005" undersized, so I reduced by .013" to 1.237".

The laser hole was too closed after the print and I had to drill it out with a .125" bit. I would open it up more if I were to modify the design. The hole was a little hard to reach with a drill bit, so I had to grasp the bit with only a short section in the chuck. If you try it I would recommend making a custom cylinder to center the tail rather than the screws as I think it would be easier to take the boresighter in and out that way. The cone that the boresighter rests in seems to work fine as long as the scope is oriented with the focus tube mostly up. If the boresighter slips out of the centering cone the collimation will be off. I turn the boresighter on and off by pushing down and twisting the tail of the boresighter.

Collimating instructions:

  1. Be careful pointing a laser toward your eye. I take no responsibility for damage that could occur to your eye. Do this at your own risk.
  2. Insert the boresighter in the collimator and center the tail.
  3. Insert the collimator in the focusing tube of your scope in the eyepiece position. You might as well orient the viewing window on the collimator so you can see it while adjusting the primary screws.
  4. Adjust the secondary mirror until the laser dot is centered in the primary mirror center (it helps to have an annulus/donut center mark on your primary). You will have to look down the tube to see the dot on the primary.
  5. Flip the telescope so that you're looking at primary adjustment screws. You should be able to see the sight window in the collimator.
  6. Adjust primary adjustment screws until the laser dot in the sight window is centered. If your primary is so far out of alignment that you can't see a dot you might have to pull the collimator out and adjust the primary until your eye is visible when you look into the focusing tube.

That's it. It's MUCH faster than what I used to do with a pinhole sighting jig that I made. I can collimate now in about a minute.

One thing that really stands out to me now that I have this working is that I can easily change the collimation by rotating the scope on the mount. i.e. Gravity is taking my scope out of collimation when the scope changes orientation. While I'm not sure how much it affects my viewing, I suspect it's fairly significant and is an indication that I should tighten up the tolerances on the parts that are moving or perhaps manipulate them while viewing to see if I can get better views. Pretty cool!

Laser Boresighter
https://www.amazon.com/Bushnell-Bushnell-Laser-Boresighter-22-50-Cal/dp/B0105RMBEA/ref=sr_1_8?ie=UTF8&qid=1488716474&sr=8-8&keywords=laser+boresighter

comments.text: Okay, printed out one and tried putting it together. I found that I could keep with M3 screws if I do the following:
comments.author: WingedPower

comments.text:
After seeing this, I purchased some M-6151 (3/4") rollers to put on a standard carriage from the GitHub Mini-Kossel set obtained from the Pay-It-Forward thread on the DeltaBot Google group and tried it on MakerBeam. It came up loose also. Today I bought some M-6153 (7/8") rollers. Using two M-6151 rollers on the fixed side and one M-6153 on the adjustable leg results in a nice fit with no filing needed. I'm betting this combination will work nicely on the Misumi 1515 as well.
Ray ( Watch my handle for an improved extruder for Bowden, direct and hybrid and a really fast heating hot end. )
comments.author: WingedPower

comments.text: Upon further examination I find this part to have a major flaw. You can see in the main picture that the top is not square to the vertical beam. This will cause the effector rod ball joints to not be parallel to the build surface, hence an impossible to calibrate printer. See https://groups.google.com/forum/#!topic/deltabot/ic1IGNwNoKchttps://groups.google.com/foru... for more in depth explanation.
comments.author: WildKata

comments.text: It's hard to tell from that slightly offset angle, but the top does appear to be perfectly parallel to the horizontal beam behind it. As long as the two-roller side is straight —meaning that the carriage is tight— the top should remain perfectly flat. The thing I would worry about, with play in the carriages, is that the effector might be loose enough to allow the Bowden tube and hotend wires to wiggle it around. I'm building a delta using these carriages, and will have to see how it performs.
comments.author: WildKata

comments.text: Being square to the beam it is on is the important thing.  Did you look at the picture I linked?

description.text:
This piece is a cover for the pointless hole above the seat heating buttons in the Fiesta ST MK7. It was inspired by the cover put into the Fiesta ST200 which I think does not really fit to the car, because of its brushed metal look.

Simply print out both pieces, stick them together and glue them. They should just perfectly fit into the hole.

The tolerances in this model are quiet high due to my low-cost printer model. If you need a tighter spacing feel free to pm me. I will try to soon upload .step files also to make customizing easier.

EDIT:

Now added *.igs files for easier customization.

Printer:

CTC Bizer

Rafts:

Doesn't Matter

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.3

Infill:

100%

Notes:

For material I chose FormFutura Titan X in grey and Apollo X in red.

Because I didn't like to have the 3D printing lines in the final piece I decided to sandpaper it (120,500,2000), then post process both pieces with XTC 3D, then sandpaper again and finally recolor it. I found that a mixture of 10% RAL 9005 and 90% RAL 9021 colors (both with a mat finish) was fiting quiet well. If you don't like to mix colors you can also use just RAL 9021 only, but it is slightly too bright. If anyone has the original color of the plastic below feel free to comment it. For the ST logo is used a RAL 3002 ferrari-red with a glossy finish.

Additional parts:
-Two or three M3 screws (length 10mm) and nuts (aliexpress, $2)
-A carbon sheet 200x300x0.5mm (aliexpress, $10)
-Silicone remover (e.g. acetone) to initially remove silicon from the carbon sheet

Put the two printed parts and the carbon sheet together as shown in picture three, then put two or three screws through the holes and tighten the structure with the nuts firmly (the upper part should bend). Put the clamps around the z-axis bearings of the printer and push everything down softly until the carbon sheet is perfectly aligned to the heated bed. Level the print head again and you're ready to print on carbon.

As there are only two clamps connecting to the z-axis bearings it is fast to install, and to remove the build plate after a print (no need to wait for the heated bed to cool down in order to remove a part). While there are only two clamps it is still perfectly stable. All parts (incl. screws) are out of reach of the print head, no matter how you mount it - crashing the print head is impossible.

Printer:

Qidi Avatar IV

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

0.2mm layer height

Infill:

100%

Notes:

Printed with ABS.
PETG and Nylon should be ok as well.
PLA will not work as it is too brittle.

Printing on carbon

I printed on carbon with ABS, PLA (0.1mm and 0.2mm layer height) and PETG (0.4mm layer height), without any extra glue or hairspray:
-ABS needs additional support to prevent warping. I usually print a large square of 0.1mm or 0.2mm height together with the part. That square is easily removable.
-PLA needs support for proper adhesion. I uses the same support as ABS.
-PETG doesn't need any extra support.
-All parts get loose when cooling down.

I have this setup for a few months now, without any problems.

Others

I would recommend to remove the blue build material that came with the printer from the heated bed, as this will minimize heating time (You must remove the heated bed to do this. Use heat to soften the glue, then peel the blue material, and then use a rubber (those for pencils) to remove all remaining glue spots from the aluminum - it'll take at least 2 hours for everything). Otherwise just keep it.

It is possible to use a carbon sheet of different dimensions, however 300x200x0.5 is cheap and easy to get at aliexpress. And you can grab it with your hands without touching the print area.

Created with IceSL

clamp.lua added, can be rendered in IceSL (requires a GPU with full OpenGL 4.3 support)
It is similar to OpenSCAD with one difference: The code is rendered to a 3D model in real time.

Source:
https://members.loria.fr/Sylvain.Lefebvre/icesl/

comments.text: Interesting. Have not heard of this for a build surface before. I would like to try it. Looking on Aliexpress the sheet with shipping is $28. Not $10. I would also guess that you would still need to clip the sheet down otherwise I see it pulling upwards.
comments.author: TobyCWood

comments.text:
For aliexpress try to search for "carbon sheet 200" and sort by price (i.e. www.aliexpress.com/w/wholesale-carbon-sheet-200.html?site=glo&groupsort=1&SortType=price_asc&g=y&SearchText=carbon+sheet+200 ), those sheets are available for US$10 right now.
Clipping the sheet down to the heated bed might work, however it would most likely require to cut the sheet to the appropriate size - I'd rather get some stronger carbon (1.5mm or 3mm) if I had any issue with bending. Just having the two clamps on the back makes this thing handy for me. The 0.5mm carbon sheet is quite stiff and it didn't bend while printing. The largest ABS part I printed was 155x20x20mm, with a base of 165x30x0.2mm for better adhesion (without this support the edges would have most likely bent up).
The upward pulling forces go in both x and y direction (bending the sheet in only x or y is much easier than bending in both x and y) and therefore a lot of force is required to effectively bend the sheet in both x and y.
If you're printing very large ABS parts then it might be better to use a thicker sheet. I didn't print any very large parts with ABS, so I can't say for sure. But a stronger sheet also takes more time to heat up, and therefore I'd recommend 0.5mm.

author: Alkorin

description.text:
This toy Tower Crane is designed for 6mm thick plywood (or potentially other material), to be lasercut from 2 sheets of 600x300cm. The drawings account for 0.1mm cut width.

When assembled, the crane stands ~840mm tall (This is excluding the solid wood base). The horizontal arm ('Jib') extends ~540mm from the tower.

The hoist block can be fitted with hook or magnet.
It has 3 degrees of movement:

  • up/down (~600mm),
  • radial (trolley can slide ~380mm along the jib)
  • axial (the top part can rotate 360 degrees)

The top connects to the tower via a 25mm diameter aluminum tube, which acts as rotation axel. Metal shafts or threaded rods (4 and 6 mm) and (plastic) gears are required for actual hoisting action.

This project still is, and might always remain, in prototyping phase

The prototype shown in the pictures was lasercut from 4mm poplar ply (didn't have 6mm ply available at the time). This results in several measurements being off, like the box joints not being flush.

The current designs are the basis of the first ever iteration. They include many sizes of wheels, to be tested and tried during first construction. Several parts had to be hacked and changed to accommodate the machinery and 'hoist cables'. With the experiences and lessons learned, a second iteration should prove to be better and allow for a less hacky construction.

Jib with trolley, various post-lasercutting hacks visible Turntable with 25mm aluminum tube, hoist cable wheel and trolley crank Complete prototype, with solid wood base construction and plastic hoist gear spockets
This project was lasercut at the ZB45 Makerspace in Amsterdam: https://www.zb45.nl/, with their Trotec Speedy 100 lasercutter.

I printed scaling it down to 50% which gives an over all diameter of 25 cm : 10 inch
Noozle 0.6
No specific setting apart the support. I used the standard recommended setting of the Ultimaker 2+ with CURA 2.4.0 (2.3.x works as well)

Assembly instructions

For assembling all parts with the body you need to have a rc steel cord.
Make sure the cords fit with the holes of the body and the holder parts. These latter (holes) can be made bit larger if necessary.
Shape the cord to give the form of halfe a circle (see the picture) so it can go through each hole of the body.
Try first the shaped cord before putting the parts, normally it should go smoothly through the holes if the shape is correctly formed.
Then progressively push the cord while at the same time you put the part so it goes though it.
In general very little adjustment may be necessary for some part so to fit properly and easily

Design

This thing was made with the help of the great Tinkercad.
Edit it online https://www.tinkercad.com/things/0IxYqjChdTL

print_settings.Notes:: I found increasing the floor and ceiling to 4 layers made for a cleaner look, but your print setting might vary for this depending on you printer. No supports were required, but if your slicer supports adding custom supports, it may not be a bad idea to add a couple thin supports to the port hols on the CPU box. Though I did not find this necessary, some printers do not do bridging well.

title: Raspberry Pi 3 Mini Stand for 7" LCD Touch Display

description.text: This is a stand to hold the Raspberry Pi 7" LCD Touch screen. As many of you know, if you have attempted to use the existing stands, the display shows upside-down. Though this can be fixed with a command provided in the newer versions of Raspbian, it cant be correctly resolved if you are running Ubuntu Mate.I decided I would design my own stand to put it all together without needing to make config changes. The obvious benefit is that during the initial boot, everything is correctly orientated (you can read the boot info). There is also a small pocket space near the bottom front, to allow you a neat place to store your stylus.

Printer Brand:

MakerBot

Printer:

MakerBot Replicator 2

Rafts:

No

Supports:

No

Resolution:

.2 mm/layer

Infill:

20%

Notes:

I found increasing the floor and ceiling to 4 layers made for a cleaner look, but your print setting might vary for this depending on you printer. No supports were required, but if your slicer supports adding custom supports, it may not be a bad idea to add a couple thin supports to the port hols on the CPU box. Though I did not find this necessary, some printers do not do bridging well.

Assembly video can be found at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=2-aERy8zSjA

I wanted to make this as simple to assemble as possible. No screws are needed. You will need to glue the CPU box to the backer-board (this was sperated to prevent the need for supports in the print process). Everything else clips together. To keep the LCD in the proper location, you will need 4, .75cmX .75cm foam or felt cubes (I used a small stack of felt feet). You will also need 4 more felt squares that are .25cm thick (1 thickness felt foot pads)

1) Glue the CPU box to the Backer-Board. You will need to set it into place point first from the ribbon channel as it is recessed.

2) Assemble the LCD and Raspberry Pi. This box is designed to hold them when configured using the classic assembly method, and will not work if you invert the board for a low profile design.

3) Place the .75 felt cubes onto the marked indentations on the inside of the backer-board.

4) Place the assembled LCD/Raspberry Pi into the newly assembled back

5) Place the thinner felt pads on the inside of the bezel in each corner on the sides (see pictures)

6) Lower the Bezel over the LCD. This should only fit in 1 direction.

7) Slide the entire unit into the stand base. This will act as the "clip" that will hold the lower part of the housing together

8) Place the Top-Clip onto the top of the unit. It should fit in such a way to allow for access to the camera mount slot.

Note: If you are going to be installing the camera, you will need to first install the ribbon cable onto the Pi and feed it though the slot in the back of the CPU Box. You will not have access to this port to make the connection from the outside.

description.text:
MDF 15mm bases that I need to mount my collection of SF miniatures. The base size matches the grid squares for popular 15mm deck plans. Produces plenty of bases per sheet with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame.

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 12" x 9" (Arch A sheet size) - four of these would fit within an (Arch C) 24" x 18" sheet size or across the bed of an Epilog Helix. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

title: GEEETech i3C (METAL version): Dual Extruder FAN & LED (V2 with 3DTouch)
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - No Derivatives

description.text:
Hi,
now GEEETech proposes the Acrylic Prusa I3 pro series, B for single extruder and C for dual extruder, with metallic parts instead of original printer ones.
Quite immediately I’ve ordered the upgrade kit in order to improve the stability and the quality of my, already not-so-bad printer, unfortunately the customization I’ve designed for the plastic version of this printer cannot be used on the metal one, so I’ve started designing a completely new customization, starting with all lesson learned from my original customization!
One, main, lesson learned was to decouple all contact, in order to enable easy mounting, maintenance and upgrade!
Here the Dual Extruder FAN & LED component of my new customization!
In this design you can find place to put ties in order keep in position all cables, as you can see in my photos!
For FAN Duct you can find closed & open version, I prefer closed one but I know that lot of people can love open version!
From the V1 this V2 have “only” add the place for 3DTouch sensor that GEEETech is released to implement ABL…and to create the correct space I’ve rotate to 45° the FANS.

As usual in all my design I’ve split all in order to have an easy print of each, and also an easy mounting, with glue, after print!

PS: after the installation of this customization is a good Idea to re-execute the PID Autotest… I’ve do two time, one with fan power off and one with fan power on, and both was really different from the same test executed just couple hours before!

IF YOU “FALL IN LOVE” OF THIS DESIGN, PLEASE, REMEMBER THAT IT TAKE TIME TO BE CREATED, DESIGNED AND SHARED… SO “MAYBE” YOU CAN USE THE “TIP DESIGNED” BUTTON ON MY PROFILE!

My first nozzle rack worked fine. As time goes by, however, more nozzles tend to accumulate. I got a hold on more .04's the standard size I use. I also bought some 1.0 size after they were recommended for clear prints. Then there's the stainless nozzle for printing metal, so on and so forth. Needless to say I had to make a bigger rack.

This one also has embossed nozzle sizes, they're just hard to see because I used clear filament. The holes are sized so the nozzles can be screwed in with a wrench. While they should be easily removable by hand this will keep them from flying all over the place should the rack get knocked of the desk.

description.text:
Already popular a couple of centuries ago.
This tumbling toy is hollow and consists of a top and a bottom part. The top part is printed standing upright without support. A raft may be necessary in case the adhesion to the bed is not optimal. The bottom part is printed with a raft as well with the opening down. To enhance the tumbling effect, only the height (Z-axis) is reduced to 80%. In the bottom part a weight (about 30 grams) is glued. Keep it in the center as much as possible.
The top part is reduced in height as well. The Z-axis is printed at 70%. The top part is pushed into the bottom part.

This is a model of the Bulldog XL extruder from RRD ( http://www.reprapdiscount.com/) . I needed the model for a machine design and haven't been able to find it online so I drew it myself. Files will be added as I complete them. IPT files are from Inventor 2013. Every piece will have an STL, STP, and IPT. Extruder uses a R-1760KK bearing, not entirely sure what the KK means but it is a metal shielded bearing with an outside dimension of 17mm, thickness of 6mm and a bore of 6mm. There is a brass sleeve which I have uploaded that is pressed into the bore to allow the use of an M3 screw. Link to bearing dimensions/specs - http://www.nmbtc.com/bearings/part-numbers/search/R-1760ZZ/6131 Gearbox is 5.18:1, rough drawing uploaded. Length from base of gearbox to tip of drive spindle is correct along with diameter of spindle. Spindle is 8mm, width from flat to side is 7mm, flat is 15mm long. I may clean this model up more but it's usable as is. Stepper motor is roughly 34mm long from machined face to back, max current of 1.0 amp and recommended current of 0.6 amp. No further information found. Assembly has been added, still missing a few parts needed for complete model (gearbox cover, hobbed pulley, bearing, groovemount clamp, and interchangeable brass plugs). Once I have all files done, I will do an assembly and check fitment and adjust any files necessary so keep that in mind.

title: Full Scale Portal Gun [Remix] repaired STL file

description.text:
This is a replacement for "Portal_Gun_White_Left_Shell_Slice_6.stl" in thing #26027.
The original file specified a triangle count of 6964 triangles, but reached end of file after 6963, so was an invalid STL format. Some tools would refuse to read it; others would read it, but you'd have a hole or perhaps a corrupted final triangle.
This is identical to the original file, but with the missing triangle added to the end.

Get all the files from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:26027 and then replace the file "Portal_Gun_White_Left_Shell_Slice_6.stl" with this one. Follow all the instructions & cautions on the original.

Have you ever wanted to interact and control a spacecraft? The Cosmoneer Proto Stand is a simple design that simulates the low-friction zero-g environment of space. Wireless power and adjustable height simulate solar power and day/night. Use this with the Cosmoneer Proto for a 1DOF desktop satellite simulator.

Notes:

These are all the parts required to print a complete Cosmoneer Proto 1DOF Stand. You will need additional parts to complete this build:

They are:

  • 5v Wireless Inductive charging Coil & Trasmitter PCB
  • 5.5 x 2.1mm Female DC power socket
  • 4" Tie wraps (Qty 3)
  • String & Hook (or equivalent)

The Hanger arms are more fragile when printed in PLA. ABS printing is successful on the Cube 3 with a modified Cube 3 printer.

The modified Cube 3 has the fiollowing:

  • Heated print bed
  • Borosilicate glass plate
  • Printe bed plastic is removed and magnets epoxied with high-temp epoxy
  • Non-3D systems ABS filament

When using a heated print bed, set the heat to 95 degrees C when the first layer is being printed. Temp can be lowered to 85 degrees C after the first layer is printed.

3D systems Cube 3 glue adhesive is used when printing these ABS parts for successful bed adhesion. Glue is applied when the bed is up to temp.

Full assembly instructions on Instructables are found here:
https://www.instructables.com/id/Assembling-a-Cosmoneer-Proto-Stand/

description.text:
An "update" on my earlier filamentguidegluesticktrimmerholder thing #2043802
I leave all my filament out in the open on a rack made from pvc pipe. I don't think I've had any trouble with moisture yet, but I thought I'd try an experimental dryer mod.

I designed a cylinder that should be big enough to hold two of those silicate bags that come with filament, seaweed (yes I did say seaweed), all that other kind of moisture absorbingg stuff. The hope is that the silicate will absorb the moisture from the filament as it slowly passes through the dryer.

I used the filament holder I used for the previous thing. I also used the hinge and latch from the filter on the same file.

Like the previous thing, I haven't had the chance to print it yet. Not sure if it actually works.

title: Lasercut 40mm wide MDF Skirmish Rules Miniature Bases - Assorted
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A range of MDF 40mm wide bases for several popular skirmish miniature games. I cut some smaller sized bases on a friends request and used them as filler on my other projects (outer perimeter of the include pic). I have compiled those and a range of other sizes based on information I found @ http://philbancients.blogspot.ca/2010/02/field-of-glory-training-manual-basing.html

Formatted for cutting on 3mm MDF cut from 12" x 9" (Arch A sheet size) - four of these would fit within an (Arch C) 24" x 18" sheet size or across the bed of an Epilog Helix. Produces plenty of bases per sheet with a minimum 0.5" safety margin around edge of the frame. I have provided the PDF and a SVG files that I converted online at https://cloudconvert.com/vsd-to-svg. Shared as is.

If you are inclined to be more than a taker and a consumer, pay forward by contributing to this site, as so many others have before you, or perform a random act of kindness, or donate to a good cause when the opportunity next arises. If you liked it enough to download it I'd appreciate a LIKE, it helps get the word out and spread these designs around. That is all.

author: jammer859

description.text:
For person with a handicap they made a special Toilet-seat on steel frame, some 20 years ago. The seat was broken and new ones nowhere available. So I printed a new for him.
Total thickness 6 to 8 mm. Weight of the final product: 2,2 kg.
Printed with Titan extruder + Volcano, nozzle 0,6 mm, layer height 0,4mm. on my CoreXY printer on which I can print max. dimensions 500x500x250 mm.
Total printtime: 72 hours. Weight of the final product: 2,2 kg.
Solid material : PLA, 3 mm.
After printing I grinded the product with sanding paper by hand: corn 120.
For smoothness I added 2 layers XTC-3D paint.

These twin containers should slide into each other smoothly.
You can adjust the following parameters in customiser:

Render resoltuion: $fn=100;
Object height in mm
rotation in degrees (try 90, 180, 360)
thickness= object wall thicness in mm. My default value is very thin. Almost 1 layer.
First side of ellips in mm: side1
Second side of ellips in mm: side2
Base thickness in mm base (no need to modify this value)
space mm. Empty space between two shapes in mm's, Adjust this value so that two objects smoothly slide into each other without friction, or with minimal friction.Default is 0.8mm. Increase if the friction is too high or objects do not slide at all. Leave as default for your first print.

The following short video shows how they should slide:
https://youtu.be/Z48QfeoI2Ew?t=5s

Use this tool to easy open a DRIFT Camera, even in cold or wet conditions.
It is designed for a Ghost-S. But if You use a Drift Stealth, just decrease the design by 0.87 and it fits also there!!
The tool is very small and takes not much space. Therefore You can put it into your box or bag, where You are carrying Your camera and the stuff for it.
Please do not judge the quality on the pictures as these parts are only my first prototypes. Tune Your printer settings to achieve more accurate models.
As I own the models Ghost-S and Stealth-2 from DRIFT, I can ensure, that the tool works fine there. It may fit to other models - just try it and leave a comment!
Thank You for sharing ;-)

The space for beans in the Autentica is small enough for it to constantly make me want to top it up. To overcome this, I've crafted this large hopper which can just be push-fit into the top. The original lid then fits on top. The original lid has a hole in it aligned with the place which alledgedly is for putting pre-ground coffee in, but I just don't use that. In any case, the hole need filling to prevent dust getting into the coffee, so that's what the plug is for.

Enjoy.

Thanks. Time consuming it surely is. I ended up using Sketchup (Pro-version as long as that's in trial mode) with an extension for making my object Solid, watertight. In combination with Cura. And my first attempt did fit !!! Some minor details adjusted and now I have my first real-world applicable object! Cool! Here it is: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2477252
Immediately improved version 2, which is bigger, but having it printed costs 45 euro. Which is a waste of money, since I already have the small one, but I did publish that too, since someone might want it. Here version 2 is https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2476630
Lovely. On to the next object.
